history.content:
You'll be fine without Math 1B before EE16A. There is nothing in Math 1B that is taught or is a true prerequisite to anything taught in EE 16A. The only times when calculus was present in EE 16A, it was usually used theoretically in circuit design as opposed to the actual solving of any calculus problems. The only thing that might be a concern is mathematical maturity and the ability to think theoretically in terms of calculus concepts, but given that you're a senior in CS/EECS, I doubt that will be a problem. Best of luck!

======================================================================

As long as you know how to take an integral, you should be fine. 

source: former 16A TA

You'll be fine without Math 1B before EE16A. There is nothing in Math 1B that is taught or is a true prerequisite to anything taught in EE 16A. The only times when calculus was present in EE 16A, it was usually used theoretically in circuit design as opposed to the actual solving of any calculus problems. The only thing that might be a concern is mathematical maturity and the ability to think theoretically in terms of calculus concepts, but given that you're a senior in CS/EECS, I doubt that will be a problem. Best of luck!

children.subject: Just wanted to add that I took EE16A last fall and Math 1B last spring for the same reason as you (Math 1B filled up too fast in the fall), and it wasn't a problem at all for me to take them in that order.

history.content:
Math 1B is not a full prerequisite to EE16A. However, because of concerns about maturity, it is recommended that freshmen without Calc BC AP or equivalent to take 16A after having taken Math 1A or 1B at Berkeley.  After all, in the Berkeley admissions context, there's presumably some *reason* someone doesn't have CalcBC AP or equivalent as an incoming students. 

In general, it is troubling and not a good idea for students to take courses wildly out of order. We understand that since the 16 series came on line as core freshmen (and incoming transfer) courses, there were some students caught in the transition. This shouldn't impact incoming students who really need to take 16AB as soon as possible.

I changed my scheduling for summer/fall, and am now stuck in a position where I am a senior who needs to take Math 1B and EE16A, but Math1B is closed. I spoke to some friends who said although it is listed as a prerequisite, Math1B is not necessary for doing well in EE16A. Do people agree? Or am I stuck taking Math1B and EE16A and Math54 in the Spring?
history.subject: Math 1B required for EE16A
